CHAPTER 1501
General Provisions
1501.01   Adoption of Ohio Fire Code.
1501.02   Alternate methods and materials.
1501.03   Appeals.
1501.04   Prohibition; civil penalties.
1501.05   Remedies.
1501.99   Penalty.
 
1501.01 ADOPTION OF OHIO FIRE CODE.
   The City shall utilize and enforce the Ohio Fire Code, which is promulgated
by the State Fire Marshal. The Chief of the Fire Prevention Bureau may, with
the approval of the Fire Chief, make inspections, write violations and
institute enforcement proceedings pursuant to the Ohio Fire Code. (Ord. 156-
2024. Passed 8-12-24.)
1501.02 ALTERNATE METHODS AND MATERIALS.
   The Chief of the Fire Prevention Bureau may, with the approval of the Fire
Chief, approve the use of a material or method of work not specifically
prescribed by the Ohio Fire Code. The approval of such alternative shall comply
with the intent of the provisions of the Ohio Fire Code. The material, method
or work offered shall be, for the purpose intended, at least the equivalent of
that prescribed in the Ohio Fire Code in quality, strength, effectiveness, fire
resistance, durability and safety.    
(Ord. 156-2024. Passed 8-12-24.)
1501.03 APPEALS.
   (a)    Any person, firm or corporation against whom an order is served, to
include a notice of violation, citation or revocation, suspension or denial of
the issuance of a license or permit pursuant to this Fire Prevention Code, may
within five days of the service of such order appeal to the Fire Chief in
writing. The Fire Chief shall, within five days of receipt of the appeal,
review such order and shall issue a decision affirming, vacating or modifying
the order appealed from.
   (b)   The decision of the Fire Chief may be further appealed to the Director
of Public Service/Safety by filing a written notice of appeal within ten days
from date of the Fire Chief's decision. The Director shall conduct a hearing
when requested and shall within seven days of the hearing issue a decision
affirming, vacating or modifying the decision of the Fire Chief.
   (c)   Any decision concerning the revocation, suspension or denial of a
license may thereafter be appealed to the City License Appeals Board pursuant
to the provisions of Chapter
149 of the Codified Ordinances of the City. Any other decision of the Director
concerning any order issued pursuant to this Code may be appealed in the manner
required by law.
   (d)   The filing of any appeal under this section shall not suspend any
order appealed from or relieve the person against whom any order is issued from
immediate compliance with the order when there is actual or potential danger to
any occupants or any person in the proximity of any building, structure or
premises because of unsafe structural conditions, inadequacy of any means of
egress, the presence of explosives, explosive fumes or vapors, the presence of
toxic fumes, gases or materials, or any other dangerous condition in the
opinion of the Fire Prevention Bureau, which requires the immediate evacuation
of such building, structure or premises.
(Ord. 281-87. Passed 12-21-87.)
1501.04 PROHIBITION; CIVIL PENALTIES.
   (a)    No person shall knowingly violate any provision of the Ohio Fire Code
or any order made pursuant to these Codes.
 
   (b)    Any person who has received a citation for a violation of the Ohio
Fire Code or any order issued pursuant to these codes may be assessed a civil
penalty of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000) for each such violation
in addition to any criminal penalty.
(Ord. 156-2024. Passed 8-12-24.)
   (c)    Any person who fails to correct a violation for which a citation has
been issued within the period permitted for its correction may be assessed a
civil penalty of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000) for each day
during which such failure or violation continues.
   (d)   Any person who violates any of the posting requirements, as prescribed
by Ohio R.C. 3737.42(C), may be assessed a civil penalty of not more than one
thousand dollars ($1,000) for each violation in addition to any criminal
penalty.
   (e)   Due consideration to the appropriateness of the penalty with respect
to the gravity of the violation, the good faith of the person being charged,
and the history of previous violations shall be given whenever a penalty is
assessed under this chapter.
   (f)   Civil penalties imposed by this chapter shall be paid to the City for
deposit into the general revenue fund. Such penalties may be recovered in a
civil action in the name of the City brought in the court of common pleas.
(Ord. 281-87. Passed 12-21-87.)
1501.05 REMEDIES.
   The imposition of the civil and criminal penalties herein described shall
not prevent the Law Director from instituting appropriate action to prevent
unlawful construction or to restrain, correct or abate a violation; or to
prevent an illegal occupancy of a building, structure or premises; or to stop
an illegal act, conduct of business or use of a building or structure in or
about any premises. Upon the request of the Chief of the Fire Prevention
Bureau, or his inspector, the Law Director shall institute and prosecute such
actions as he deems necessary in order to enforce the provisions of this
chapter. (Ord. 281-87. Passed 12-21-87.)
1501.99 PENALTY.
   Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this
chapter or the Ohio Fire Code or failing to comply with any order issued
pursuant to any section thereof, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the first
degree. Each day that a violation continues, after service of notice as
provided for in the Ohio Fire Code, shall be deemed a separate offense.
(Ord. 156-2024. Passed 8-12-24.)
CHAPTER 1503
Bureau of Fire Prevention
1503.01   Establishment.
1503.02   Bureau Chief; designation and term.
1503.03   Appointment of inspectors or investigators.
1503.04   Duties of Bureau.
1503.05   Appointment of arson investigators; duties; training.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Enforcement of Ohio Fire Code - see FIRE PREV.
1511.01
 
1503.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   A Bureau of Fire Prevention in the Fire Department of the City is hereby
established which shall be operated under the supervision of the Chief of the
Fire Department.
(1964 Code §601.02; Ord. 281-87. Passed 12-21-87.)
1503.02 BUREAU CHIEF; DESIGNATION AND TERM.
   The Chief of the Fire Department shall designate an officer or member of the
Fire Department as Chief of the Bureau of Fire Prevention, who shall hold such
office at the pleasure of the Chief of the Fire Department.
(1964 Code §601.03; Ord. 281-87. Passed 12-21-87.)
1503.03 APPOINTMENT OF INSPECTORS OR INVESTIGATORS.
   (a)    The Chief of the Fire Department may detail such other members of the
Fire Department as inspectors or investigators as shall from time to time be
necessary.
(1964 Code §601.04)
   (b)    The Chief of the Fire Department shall recommend to Council the
employment of technical inspectors, who, when such authorization is made, shall
be selected through an examination to determine their fitness for the position.
The examination shall be open to members and nonmembers of the Fire Department,
and appointments made after examination shall be for an indefinite term with
removal only for cause.
(1964 Code §601.05; Ord. 281-87. Passed 12-21-87.)
1503.04 DUTIES OF BUREAU.
   (a)   It shall be the duty of the officers of the Bureau of Fire Prevention
to enforce all laws and ordinances covering the following:
      (1)    The prevention of fires;
      (2)    The storage and use of explosives and flammables;
      (3)    The installation and maintenance of automatic and other private
fire alarm systems and fire extinguishing equipment;
      (4)    The maintenance and regulation of fire escapes;
      (5)    The maintenance of protection and the elimination of hazards in
buildings and structures, including those under construction;
      (6)    The means and adequacy of exit in case of fire, from factories,
schools, hotels, lodging houses, asylums, hospitals, churches, halls, theaters
and all other places in which numbers of persons work, live or congregate, from
time to time, for any purpose;
      (7)    The investigation of the cause, origin and circumstances of fires.
   (b)   The Bureau shall have such other powers and perform such other duties
as are set forth in other ordinances, and as may be conferred and imposed from
time to time by law.
(1964 Code §601.06; Ord. 281-87. Passed 12-21-87.)
1503.05 APPOINTMENT OF ARSON INVESTIGATORS; DUTIES; TRAINING.
   (a)   Pursuant to the authority provided in Ohio R.C. 737.27, the Director
of Public Safety is hereby authorized to assign members of the Fire Prevention
Bureau as arson investigators, who shall have the power and duty to be present
at all fires, investigate the cause thereof, examine witnesses, compel the
attendance of witnesses and the production of books and papers, and to do and
perform all other acts necessary to the effective discharge of such duties.
Such officer may administer oaths, make arrests and enter, for the purpose of
examination, any building which, in his opinion, is in danger from fire.
   (b)   Arson investigators appointed pursuant to this section shall be
empowered to carry a firearm which may be used for the purpose of self-defense.
Arson investigators shall obtain training in the use of firearms, and such
other training in the areas of police investigatory and arrest techniques, as
the Director shall establish. (Ord. 39-93. Passed 3-1-93.)
CHAPTER 1505
Fire Protection Systems
1505.01   Definitions.
1505.02   Purpose and scope.
1505.03   Buildings accommodating more than twenty persons.
1505.04   Buildings accommodating more than five and not more than twenty
individuals.
1505.05   Multi-family dwellings in excess of three residential units.
1505.06   Fire extinguisher requirements in buildings and multi-family
dwellings.
1505.07   Time period for installation of fire protection systems.
1505.99   Penalty.
 
1505.01 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   "Building" means a hotel, motel, lodging house, boarding house or
college dormitory used for shelter and sleeping purposes.
   (b)   "Multi-family dwelling" means an apartment or condominium having more
than three residential units rented or leased to tenant or owned and operated
by an association of owners, and which is seventy-five feet or less in height.
   (c)   "Smoke detector" means a readily removable device sensitive and
responsive to any products of combustion or combination of such products,
except detectors which are sensitive to and respond to heat only. Detectors
shall utilize a photo-electric cell or ionization chamber. Detectors, devices,
equipment and components shall be approved or listed for the purposes for which
they are intended by the Underwriters Laboratory, Inc. or other approved
testing laboratory.
(Ord. 212-84. Passed 12-10-84; Ord. 281-87. Passed 1-21-87.)
1505.02 PURPOSE AND SCOPE.
    The purpose of this chapter is to establish minimum fire protection
standards for buildings and multi-family dwellings that were not required to
install smoke detectors, fire alarm system or fire extinguishers, when the
building or multi-family dwelling was constructed. Where smoke detectors, fire
alarm systems or fire extinguishers were or are installed in buildings or
multi-family dwellings in conformity with a higher or more restrictive standard
of Ohio's Basic Building Code than is required by the provisions of this
chapter, then the Ohio Basic Building Code shall be the applicable standard.
(Ord. 212-84. Passed 12-10-84; Ord. 281-87. Passed 12-21-87.)
1505.03 BUILDINGS ACCOMMODATING MORE THAN TWENTY PERSONS.
   (a)   All existing buildings with an occupant load of more than twenty shall
be provided with an automatic fire alarm system. Additionally, a single station
smoke detector shall be installed in such a manner and location that it shall
provide an alarm suitable to warn the occupants within the individual guest
room, suite or sleeping area. The manner and location of the detector shall be
approved by the Fire Prevention Bureau. In buildings having basements or
cellars, an additional smoke detector shall be installed in the basement or
cellar in a location approved by the Fire Prevention Bureau.
   (b)   For purposes of installation and maintenance, the automatic fire alarm
system and/or single station smoke detector shall comply with the applicable
section of the National Fire Protection Association approved standards and
primary power shall be by alternating current (AC), noncord connected.
(Ord. 212-84. Passed 12-10-84; Ord. 281-87. Passed 12-21-87.)
1505.04 BUILDINGS ACCOMMODATING MORE THAN FIVE AND NOT MORE THAN TWENTY
INDIVIDUALS.
   (a)   All existing buildings with an occupant load of more than five and not
more than twenty shall be provided with a single station smoke detector
installed in such a manner and location that it shall provide an alarm suitable
to warn the occupants within the individual guest room, suite or sleeping area.
The manner and location of the detector shall be approved by the Fire
Prevention Bureau. In buildings having basements or cellars, an additional
smoke detector shall be installed in the basement or cellar in a location
approved by the Fire Prevention Bureau.
   (b)   Smoke detectors installed in existing buildings in conformity with
this chapter may be battery operated so long as the detector is inspected at
least once every six months by the owner or agent of the property to insure
that the battery is maintained in good working order.
   (c)   If, upon inspection, the Fire Prevention Bureau determines that
battery operated smoke detectors installed in conformity with subsection (b)
hereof, are inoperable, defective or not being maintained in good working
order, then the Fire Prevention Bureau may order the property owner or his
agent to install smoke detectors with primary power by alternating current,
noncord connected in compliance with the applicable section of the National
Fire Protection Association's approved standards.
(Ord. 212-84. Passed 12-10-84; Ord. 281-87. Passed 12-21-87.)
1505.05 MULTI-FAMILY DWELLINGS IN EXCESS OF THREE RESIDENTIAL UNITS.
   (a)   All existing multi-family dwellings having more than three dwelling
units shall be provided with a minimum of one single station smoke detector in
each dwelling unit. It shall be installed in a manner and location approved by
the Canton Fire Prevention Bureau. In buildings having basements or cellars, an
additional smoke detector shall be installed in the basement or cellar in a
location approved by the Fire Prevention Bureau.
   (b)   Smoke detectors installed in existing multi-family dwellings in
conformity with this chapter may be battery operated, so long as the detector
is inspected at least once every six months by the owner or agent of the
property to insure that the battery is maintained in good working order.
   (c)   If, upon inspection, the Fire Prevention Bureau determines that
battery operated smoke detectors installed in conformity with subsection (b)
hereof, are inoperable, defective or not being maintained in good working
order, then the Fire Prevention Bureau may order the property owner or his
agent to install smoke detectors with primary power by alternating current,
noncord connected in compliance with the applicable section of the National
Fire Protection Association's approved standards.
(Ord. 212-84. Passed 12-10-84; Ord. 281-87. Passed 12-21-87.)
1505.06 FIRE EXTINGUISHER REQUIREMENTS IN BUILDINGS AND MULTI-FAMILY DWELLINGS.
   All existing multi-family dwellings having more than three dwelling units,
and all existing buildings with an occupant load of more than five shall be
provided with fire extinguishers in such number and locations as determined by
the Fire Prevention Bureau in a manner that takes into account the unique
characteristics of such building or multi-family dwelling.
(Ord. 212-84. Passed 12-10-84; Ord. 281-87. Passed 12-21-87.)
1505.07 TIME PERIOD FOR INSTALLATION OF FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEMS.
   All buildings and/or multi-family dwellings which require the installation
of automatic fire alarm systems and/or single station smoke detectors shall
have the required alarm systems and smoke detectors installed not later than
ninety days after inspection by the Fire Prevention Bureau, which inspection
report shall be made in writing and a copy furnished to the owner, agent,
lessor or manager of a building or multi-family dwelling.
(Ord. 212-84. Passed 12-10-84; Ord. 281-87. Passed 12-21-87.)
1505.99 PENALTY.
   Any owner, agent, lessor or manager of a building or multi-family dwelling
who violates any provision of this chapter or who fails to comply with a lawful
order issued pursuant thereto, shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars
($100.00) for the first offense. Each day of a continuing violation shall
constitute a separate offense. Whoever violates any provision of this chapter
for a second or subsequent offense shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the
fourth degree.
(Ord. 212-84. Passed 12-10-84; Ord. 281-87. Passed 12-21-87.)

CHAPTER 1509
Aboveground and Underground Tank Storage
1509.01   Purpose.
1509.02   Bond and insurance requirements.
1509.03   Permit required.
1509.04   Installation, removal, repair or alteration standards.
1509.05   Permit fees.
1509.99   Penalty.
 
1509.01 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter shall be to ensure safe and controlled methods
for the installation, removal, repair or alteration of aboveground and
underground storage tanks for the storage of combustible or flammable liquids.
(Ord. 118-91. Passed 7-1-91.)
1509.02 BOND AND INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   No person, firm or corporation shall engage in the installation,
removal, repair or alteration of any aboveground or underground tank or be
employed or hired as a contractor or subcontractor without meeting the bonding,
insurance and permit requirements of this chapter.
 
   (b)   No permit shall be granted to any person, firm or corporation desiring
to install, remove, repair or alter any aboveground or underground storage tank
unless the applicant shall give a surety bond to the City in the sum of ten
thousand dollars ($10,000) on the condition that such applicant shall pay any
and all damage and injuries which may occur to any private or public property;
and that such applicant shall save, indemnify and hold harmless the City
against all liabilities, judgments, costs and expenses which may in any way
accrue against the City in consequence of the granting of such permit, and
shall in all things strictly comply with the conditions of his permit.
 
   (c)   No permit shall be granted to any person, firm or corporation desiring
to install, remove, repair or alter any aboveground or underground storage tank
unless the applicant shall provide evidence of liability insurance of not less
than two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000) for personal liability and
fifty thousand dollars ($50,000) for property liability and certification
showing all employees of the applicant are covered by Ohio Workers'
Compensation or equivalent insurance.
(Ord. 118-91. Passed 7-1-91.)
1509.03 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person, firm or corporation shall commence to install, remove, repair or
alter an aboveground or underground storage tank without first obtaining a
permit from the Fire Prevention Bureau. Permits are valid for six (6) months
from the date of issuance.
(Ord. 156-2024. Passed 8-12-24.)
1509.04 INSTALLATION, REMOVAL, REPAIR OR ALTERATION STANDARDS.
     Any person, firm or corporation installing, removing, repairing or
altering any aboveground or underground storage tank shall meet the
requirements set forth in Ohio Fire Code Chapter 119 (ORC 3737.02, 3737.882;
Ord. 156-2024. Passed 8-12-24.)
 
1509.05 PERMIT FEES.
   (a)   Applications for permits for the installation, modification, repair,
removal or abandonment of aboveground and underground storage tanks shall be
accompanied by payment of the following fees:
      (1)   System installation   $125.00 per system
      (2)   Tank upgrade          150.00 per tank
      (3)   Tank repair           100.00 per tank
      (4)   Tank removal          175.00 per tank
      (5)   Tank replacement      200.00 per tank
      (6)   Temporarily out of ser175.00 per system
      (7)   Piping replacement (on175.00 per location
      (8)   Piping upgrade (only) 75.00 per location
      (9)   Piping repair         75.00 per location
      (10)   Piping installation (75.00 per location
      (11)   Piping removal (only)175.00 per location
      (12)   Leak detection upgrad75.00 per location
      (13)   Tank abandonment (in 175.00 per tank
      (14)   Piping abandonment (i175.00 per location
      (15)   System change in serv150.00 per system
   NOTE: Items (1) - (12) are applicable to both aboveground and underground
storage tanks; items (13) - (15) are applicable to underground storage tanks
only.
(Ord. 156-2024. Passed 8-12-24.)
 
   (b)   The foregoing permit fees shall be paid to the Fire Prevention Bureau
prior to the beginning of any work concerning such uses. Any person, firm or
corporation who fails to obtain permits required by this chapter prior to the
beginning of work shall be required to obtain and pay for the permits which
were originally required and in addition thereto shall pay a penalty twice the
amount of the original permit fees. (Ord. 14-2000. Passed 1-31-00.)
1509.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the requirements or provisions of this chapter shall
be guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree.
(Ord. 118-91. Passed 7-1-91.)

CHAPTER 1513
Recreational Fires
1513.01   Definition and exemption.
1513.02   Application, location, material, size and duration.
1513.03   Prohibited open burning.
1513.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Air pollution control - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 3704
Permit to burn construction debris - see Ohio R.C. 3704.11(C)
Spreading fire through negligence - see Ohio R.C. 3737.62
Open burning - see OAC Ch. 3745
 
1513.01 DEFINITION AND EXEMPTION.
   (a)   Definition. “Recreational fire” is defined for the purpose of this
chapter as an outdoor fire burning seasoned dry firewood for pleasure,
religious, ceremonial, cooking, warmth or similar purposes. (Ord. 236-2007.
Passed 12-10-07.)
   (b)   Exemption. A small fire contained in a non-commercial clean burning
enclosed cooking apparatus, commonly known as a grill, which is fueled by
charcoal, propane or natural gas or similar material is exempt from the
application requirement prescribed in Section
1513.02 . (Ord. 207-2001. Passed 9-24-01.)
1513.02 APPLICATION, LOCATION, MATERIAL, SIZE AND DURATION.
   (a)   Application. Application for recreational fires shall be submitted to
the Fire Prevention Bureau for approval at least forty-eight (48) hours before
the fire is set. If a recreational fire is planned for a weekend or holiday,
notification shall be given by 3:00 p.m. Friday or by 3:00 p.m. on the last
business day before the holiday. The following information shall be provided at
the time the approval is requested:
      (1)   The purpose of the fire;
      (2)   The nature and quantities of the material to be burned;
      (3)   The date, time and duration of the fire;
      (4)   The location;
      (5)   The fire-extinguishing equipment to be provided; and
      (6)   Fire may not be started until the applicant is in receipt of an
approved permit.
         (Ord. 156-2024. Passed 8-12-24.)
   (b)   Location. The location of the fire shall not be less than twenty-five
feet from any structure.
(Ord. 236-2007. Passed 12-10-07.)
   (c)   Material. The material shall be of the minimum size for the intended
purpose, consist only of seasoned dry firewood and be ignited with a small
quantity of paper. The fuel shall be chosen to minimize the generation and
emission of air contaminants.
   (d)   Size and Duration. A recreational fire shall not be more than 2 ft. x
2 ft. x 2 ft. in dimension and shall not be permitted to burn longer than three
(3) hours, unless approved by the Fire Prevention Bureau. All recreational
fires shall be extinguished by 11:00 p.m.
   (e)   Attendance. A recreational fire shall be constantly attended until the
fire is completely extinguished. Approved extinguishing equipment shall be
available for immediate utilization at all times.
(Ord. 207-2001. Passed 9-24-01.)
1513.03 PROHIBITED OPEN BURNING.
   (a)   No person or property owner shall cause or allow open burning except
as provided in Section
1513.02.
   (b)   If a recreational fire creates or adds to a hazardous or objectionable
situation, the Fire Department shall order the property owner or person having
control to extinguish the fire. If the property owner or person having control
refuses, the Fire Department will extinguish the fire.
   (c)   If the fire is not a recreational fire which has been approved by the
Fire Prevention Bureau, or any other form of open burning for which a permit
has been issued by the Air Pollution Control Division of the Canton Health
Department, it shall be extinguished and reported to the Air Pollution Control
Division of the Canton Health Department.
(Ord. 207-2001. Passed 9-24-01.)
1513.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the requirements or provisions of this chapter shall
be guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree.
(Ord. 207-2001. Passed 9-24-01.)
CODIFIED ORDINANCES OF CANTON

CHAPTER 1701
Board of Health
1701.01    Established.
1701.02    Term of office.
1701.03    Health Commissioner.
1701.04    Meetings; duties.
1701.05    Powers.
1701.06    Recommendations to Council.
1701.07    Right of entry.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Creation - see Ohio R. C. 3709.05
Appointments - see Ohio R. C. 3709.14 et seq.
Orders and regulations - see Ohio R. C. 3709.20
 
1701.01 ESTABLISHED.
   A Board of Health of the City Health District is established pursuant to
Chapter 3709 of the Revised Code. The Board shall be composed of five members.
Four shall be appointed by the Mayor and confirmed by Council. Preference shall
be given to individuals who reside, own property or a business or work within
the corporate boundaries of the City. One member shall be appointed by the
health district licensing council established under Chapter 3709. A majority
shall constitute a quorum, and the Mayor shall be President of the Board.
(Ord. 166-2009. Passed 9-21-09.)
1701.02 TERM OF OFFICE.
   The members of the Board of Health shall serve for terms of five years each
from the date of appointment and until their successors are duly appointed and
qualified. Those first appointed shall be classified as follows: one to serve
for five years; one for four years; one for three years; one for two years, and
one for one year, and thereafter one shall be appointed each year.
(1964 Code § 211.21)
1701.03 HEALTH COMMISSIONER.
   The Board of Health shall appoint for full time service a Health
Commissioner, who shall perform such duties as may be required of him by law
and who shall receive such compensation as the Board may determine. The Board
of Health may appoint public health nurses, clerks, physicians and other
persons as they deem necessary and as provided by law.
(1964 Code § 211.22)
1701.04 MEETINGS; DUTIES.
   The Board of Health shall meet as provided by Ohio R. C. 3709.12, and shall
have the power to pass all orders and regulations as it deems necessary for the
public health and for the prevention of disease. All such orders and
regulations shall have all the force and effect as ordinances of the City.
(1964 Code § 211.23)
1701.05 POWERS.
   The Board of Health shall have the power to abate and remove all nuisances
within the City and to assess the costs of the same upon the property where
such nuisances are situated which assessment, when duly certified by the
President of the Board to the County Auditor, shall become a lien to be
collected the same as any other tax in favor of the City. The Board shall have
the power to compel the proprietors or owners, agents or assignees, occupants
or tenants of the lot or property, house or building upon or in which any such
nuisance may be, to abate and remove the same.
(1964 Code § 211.24)
1701.06 RECOMMENDATIONS TO COUNCIL.
   The Board of Health shall, from time to time, recommend to Council such
measures as they may deem necessary to promote and secure the health of the
City, and to prevent the introduction of contagious, dangerous and infectious
diseases.
(1964 Code § 211.25)
1701.07 RIGHT OF ENTRY.
   When a complaint is made, or a reasonable belief exists, that an infectious
or contagious disease prevails in any locality or house, the Board of Health
shall have the power to visit such locality or house, make all necessary
investigations by inspection and on discovery that such infectious or
contagious disease exists, to send the person so diseased to the pesthouse or
hospital.
(1964 Code § 211.26)
CHAPTER 1727
Clean Indoor Air
1727.01    Definitions.
1727.02   Restrictions on smoking in City buildings and vehicles.
1727.99    Violations and penalties.
 
1727.01  DEFINITIONS.
   The following words and phrases, whenever used in this chapter, shall be
construed as defined in this section.
   (a)   "Sign" means legible, English lettering on a contrasting background to
clearly indicate where smoking is not permitted and to provide related
information. A sign shall be of sufficient size to be clearly legible to one of
normal vision.
   (b)   "Smoking" means inhaling, exhaling, burning, or carrying any lighted
cigar, cigarette, pipe, or other lighted smoking device for burning tobacco or
any other plant. For the purposes of this chapter, smoking shall also mean the
use of any electronic smoking device, including any device that can be used to
deliver aerosolized or vaporized nicotine, or any other substance to the person
inhaling from the device (such devices are commonly known as "e-cigarettes", or
vaping).
   (c)   "Enclosed" shall mean an area that is surrounded on at least three (3)
sides by a wall or barrier at least five (5) feet high.
      (Ord. 70-2023. Passed 5-8-23.)
 
1727.02 RESTRICTIONS ON SMOKING IN CITY BUILDINGS AND VEHICLES.
   (a)    Smoking is prohibited in all areas within any City building or
enclosed facility under the control of the City of Canton. Smoking is also
prohibited in any vehicle owned or operated by the City of Canton.
 
   (b)    Smoking is prohibited within thirty (30) feet of any public entrance
to any city building or facility under control of the City of Canton.
 
   (c)    The Director of Public Service may prohibit smoking in other outside
areas to prevent the entrance of second-hand smoke or vapor from entering a
City owned building or facility or to prevent members of the public from
contact with second-hand smoke or vapor when entering or exiting a City owned
building or facility.
 
   (d)    The Director of Public Service is authorized to erect such signs as
are necessary to inform the public of this rule. (Ord. 70-2023. Passed 5-8-23.)
1727.99 VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES.
   (a)   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor.
 
   (b)    Each day on which a violation of any provision of this chapter occurs
is a separate and distinct offense and shall be punishable as such.
(Ord. 70-2023. Passed 5-8-23.)
